Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Expectation2: Maintain a safe and O39ean work environment.
Situation2: You notice a small, contained liquid spill in a walkway that needs to be O39eaned up immediately to prevent slips.
Story: I stood in the middle of the living room, my mother’s voice echoing in my ears as she handed me the ceremonial cloth. “You must lead the prayer this year,” she said, her eyes shining with pride. It was my turn to uphold our family’s tradition, to honor our ancestors and show respect. But my phone buzzed in my pocket—a message from my foreman. There was a spill on the site, right in the main walkway, and I was the closest one. If I didn’t clean it up immediately, someone could get hurt. My heart pounded as I looked at my family, gathered and waiting, and then at the message, urgent and insistent. I felt pulled in two directions, the weight of my family’s expectations pressing down on me, while the responsibility for my coworkers’ safety gnawed at my conscience. I could almost see the disappointment in my mother’s eyes if I left, and the potential for disaster if I stayed. My hands trembled as I tried to decide which duty I owed more.
